config.question: What happened to undermine the Reconstruction amendments that had protected African Americans, as well as the legislation passed to enforce them?

choices.content: The Reconstruction amendments were only symbolic; they did not contain any effective measures to protect African Americans.
African Americans were not aware of their legal rights and did not appeal to the courts for protection.
The district courts refused to honor the Reconstruction amendments and legislation passed to enforce them.
A series of Supreme Court decisions between 1878 and 1898 destroyed the amendments and the legislation that enforced them.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Plessy v. Ferguson (1896) established the doctrine of “separate but equal.” This case was not overturned until 1954 with the Brown v. Board of Education case. See L.O. 19.2 How did the growth of American cities affect social, cultural, and political life?
